persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Rewrite an escrow instructions email to remove scary legal jargon; you’re nervous because the buyer’s English is even weaker than yours and you fear they’ll back out.

conversation.content: Can you make this escrow email sound less like lawyer talk? My buyer only knows restaurant English and I think the word "contingency" is scaring him off.

Sure! I can help simplify the language and make the email sound more like everyday restaurant talk. Here's a more casual and friendly version of your escrow email:

---

**Subject:** Let’s Get This Order Moving!

Hi [Buyer's Name],

I just wanted to let you know that I’ve put your payment into escrow. Think of it like a safe place for your money until everything is ready to go. This is just to make sure everything goes smoothly on both sides.

Once the food (or product) is ready and we’re both happy with everything, I’ll send it out and you’ll get your confirmation. No need to worry — your money is safe, and I’ll make sure everything is perfect before we finish the deal.

Let me know if you have any questions or if you need more details. I’m here to help!

Thanks again,  
[Your Name]

---

If you want to include a specific detail (like a product name, delivery time, or something else), just let me know and I can tailor it even more.

No no, this is for buying a house. The escrow company sent three pages about removing loan contingency and I need it in maybe five short sentences so Mrs. Chen won't panic and walk away from her deposit.

Got it! Here's a simple, clear version of the message in plain English — no legal jargon, just five short sentences that explain what’s going on and why it’s okay:

---

Hi Mrs. Chen,

The escrow company sent some paperwork about removing the loan contingency. This just means your offer on the house is now final and you’re not backing out if the loan doesn’t go through. We’re still working on your loan, and everything is moving forward as planned. This is a normal step in the process, and your deposit is still protected. Let me know if you have any questions — I’m here to help!

---

Let me know if you want to add the house address, dates, or anything else specific.
Can you take out "contingency" and "deposit" too? She doesn't know those words. Just say "loan check" and "good-faith money" and tell her she still gets her money back if the bank says no.

Absolutely! Here's a version that uses simple, everyday language — no tricky words, just clear and reassuring:

---

Hi Mrs. Chen,

The escrow company sent some papers about the loan check. This just means your offer on the house is now final. If the bank says no to your loan, you still get your good-faith money back. This is a normal part of the process, and everything is going as planned. Let me know if you need help or have questions — I’m here for you!

---

Let me know if you'd like to personalize it with names, dates, or the house address.
Perfect. Now can you do same thing for the wire fraud warning? They put a whole page about never trust email with bank numbers but it looks like hacker letter itself.

Of course! Here's a short, simple version of the wire fraud warning — written in plain, friendly language that’s easy to understand and won’t scare anyone:

---

Hi Mrs. Chen,

Just a quick note to say: always be careful with emails that ask for bank or account numbers. Even if it looks real, it might not be. Never send money or share your banking info unless you’re 100% sure it’s from a real person you’ve talked to in person or by phone. If you ever get a message that makes you unsure, just call me right away. I’m here to help keep everything safe.

---

Let me know if you want to add your phone number or any other details.
Can you make it shorter? Like three lines max. She won't read long thing.

Sure! Here's a super short, simple version in three lines:

---

Hi Mrs. Chen,  
Don’t share bank numbers or send money unless you talk to me first. If you get a strange email, just call me. I’m here to help keep things safe.

--- 

Let me know if you want to add your phone number or anything else!
Perfect. Now I need to text the husband same thing but in Chinese. Can you write that three-line version in simple Chinese he can read on his phone?

Of course! Here's the short, simple version in **Mandarin Chinese** — easy to read on a phone, and using plain language:

如果有奇怪的邮件，直接打电话给我。我在这儿帮你们把关。

---

Or, if you want it even more casual and conversational (like a text message tone), here's a slightly simpler version:

没跟我讲之前，别汇钱或给银行号码。

Can you put the phone number line in the message? Just use 415-555-1234

Let me know if you'd like it even more slangy or with your name added!

Perfect. Now I need to write quick text to the Russian buyer's agent. He speaks English but his client only understands Russian. Can you write two-line message in English telling him to translate the wire warning to his client and double-check any bank info by calling me?
